title-group.article-title: Targeted metagenomics using probe capture detects a larger diversity of nitrogen and methane cycling genes in complex microbial communities than traditional metagenomics

abstract.p: Microbes are the key players in the global cycling of nitrogen (N) and carbon (C) processes, availability and fluxes, and losses through emission of nitrous oxide (N2O) and methane (CH4), two very potent greenhouse gases. Thus, characterization of microbial functional guilds involved in these processes is high on the political agenda. Yet, typical sequence based characterization often represents only a minor fraction of their diversity in nature due to their frequent low relative abundance, insufficient sequencing depth of traditional metagenomes of complex communities, and limitations in coverage and efficiency of PCR-based assays. Here, we developed and tested a targeted metagenomic approach based on probe capture and hybridization to simultaneously characterize the diversity of multiple key metabolic genes involved in inorganic N and CH4 cycling. We designed comprehensive probe libraries for each of the 15 selected marker genes, resulting in 264,000 unique probes in total. These probes were used to selectively enrich the target genes in shotgun metagenomic libraries. In validation experiments with a mock community of cultured microorganisms, the target gene profiles were similar to those of the original community when sequenced with targeted metagenomics. Further, relative abundances of the marker genes obtained by targeted and shotgun metagenomics from agricultural and wetland soils correlated positively, indicating that the targeted approach did not introduce a significant quantitative bias. However, targeted metagenomics generated substantially higher diversity in terms of taxonomic coverage, and a larger number of sequence reads per sample, which allowed 35 times or 18% higher diversity estimates than when using shotgun metagenomics or targeted PCR amplification, respectively. Thus, captured metagenomics complements current approaches by enabling a targeted, more detailed characterization of the diversity of key functional genes involved in N and CH4 cycling within and across ecosystems.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The global nitrogen (N) and carbon (C) cycles are essential components of the Earth’s biosphere. All major N transformation processes, i.e., nitrogen fixation, nitrification, denitrification and anammox, are performed exclusively by specific functional guilds of bacteria and archaea that are critical for ecosystem functioning. Their activities are thus crucial in regulating N availability for primary producers and microorganisms across ecosystems, as well as emissions of the potent greenhouse gas nitrous oxide (N2O) and other volatile N compounds through nitrification and denitrification. Methane (CH4) is a major product of the microbial trophic chain driving C cycling, and, like most inorganic N compounds, its production and consumption is also regulated by very specific groups of microorganisms. Importantly, CH4 is the second most potential greenhouse gas after CO2, and, together with N2O, contributes at least 25% of the total global warming caused by greenhouse gases (The global carbon project 2020, Myhre et al., 2013).

Shotgun metagenomics have been useful to provide an unbiased picture of the natural microbiome. However, in complex and diverse microbial communities, such as those found in soils and sediments, even deeply sequenced metagenomes only generate reliable information for a small fraction of the diversity of microbial functional guilds involved in inorganic N and C cycling, mainly due to their low relative abundances. Therefore, characterization of specific functional groups has long relied on PCR amplification of genes that encode key metabolic enzymes, as is well exemplified for organisms involved in various N and C cycling pathways (Knief 2015; Bräuer et al. 2021; Alves et al. 2018; Romdhane et al. 2021). However, the gene diversity involved in these biogeochemical processes captured by PCR-based approaches is limited and biased by the primers used, rendering quantitative assessments and comparisons between genes difficult. Further, in complex microbial communities, target genes of interest are encoded by a large diversity of organisms, and usually include a large fraction of novel gene sequence variants from uncharacterized organisms. The geometric expansion of genomic data has made it increasingly obvious that designing a single PCR primer pair to target the inherent diversity of metabolic genes is highly problematic (Bonilla-Rosso et al. 2016).

To improve the analysis of critical, but low abundant microbial guilds involved in N and CH4 cycling within natural communities, a probe-based targeted metagenomics approach for key genes involved in these processes could be advantageous. For eukaryotes, targeted, high-throughput sequencing approaches known as probe capture, also called hybridisation capture or hybridisation-based target enrichment, have been used to study complex eukaryotic samples such as human exons, ancient human genomes, plant transcriptomes, and cancer marker single nucleotide polymorphisms (Skoglund et al. 2014, Ichida et al. 2019, Futema et al. 2012, Kamil et al. 2021, Bewicke-Copley et al. 2019.). Different from sequence capture, where multiple probes are designed to cover a whole exon, captured metagenomics relies on large databases of multiple target genes clustered at predefined similarity cut-offs, which are used to design a large number of generic probes that are able to capture an extended sequence space for each of these sequence clusters (Kushwaha et al., 2015, Manoharan et al., 2015).

Here, we developed and tested a novel probe-based metagenomics approach targeting 15 distinct functional genes involved in inorganic N cycling (i.e., N fixation, nitrification, denitrification, anammox, and DNRA), and genes involved in CH4 production and consumption, based on newly developed gene and probe databases. To aid in the design of probe libraries to capture the diversity of N and CH4 cycling genes, the MetCap bioinformatics pipeline was developed as a protocol to produce probes from highly complex datasets for targeted metagenomics (Kushwaha et al., 2015). This approach has been successfully used earlier to identify genes involved in microbial C metabolism in soil (Manoharan et al., 2015, Manoharan et al., 2017). We evaluated our approach using mock communities comprising DNA from organisms involved in inorganic N cycling, or CH4 production or consumption with varying gene GC% content, which is known to affect probe hybridization efficiency. As proof-of-concept for use in complex communities, we used agricultural and wetland soil to compare traditional metagenomics and targeted metagenomic, and also compared the diversity of archaeal amoA genes (marker for ammonia oxidizers) and nosZ genes (marker for nitrous oxide reduction) obtained using our targeted probe capture approach with that obtained by shotgun metagenomics or PCR amplification in samples from two distinct soil types.

sec.title: Development of databases and probes for targeted metagenomics
sec.p: We compiled a total dataset of ~500,000 genes from public databases, after excluding redundant sequences and incorrect annotations, which comprised genes encoding the nitrogenase iron subunit (nifH), bacterial and archaeal ammonia monooxygenase subunit A (amoA), nitrite oxidoreductase beta subunit (nxrB), hydrazine oxidoreductase A (hzoA), formate dependent nitrite reductase (nrfA), periplasmic nitrate reductase alpha subunit (napA), respiratory nitrate reductase alpha subunit (narG), copper-containing nitrite reductase (nirK), cytochrome cd1 nitrite reductase (nirS), nitric oxide reductase B subunit (norB), nitrous oxide reductase (nosZ), particulate methane monooxygenase subunit A (pmoA), soluble methane monooxygenase component A alpha chain (mmoX), and methyl-coenzyme M reductase I subunit alpha (mcrA). This information supported the generation of ~264,000 unique gene-specific biotin-labeled probes that were used for targeting the desired sequences in DNA from samples using streptavidin coated magnetobeads (Kushwaha et al., 2015; Manoharan et al., 2015).

sec.title: Relative gene detection and quantification using targeted metagenomics
sec.p: The targeted metagenomic approach was evaluated using mock microbial communities comprising predefined mixtures of genomic DNA from 15 bacterial and three archaeal strains, together containing all 15 functional genes targeted by the probes and mixed in different proportions to produce six different median G+C contents ranging from 47% to 62% (Table S1). The overall relative abundance of target genes in the captured metagenomes across all GC% categories was strongly positively correlated with those in the original mock communities (r = 0.78 (P < 0.0001) (Fig. 1). Comparisons between the relative abundance of individual genes in the mock communities as compared to captured metagenomes revealed nearly identical values (t = 1.8518e-10, df = 174.83, P > 0.05), with the exception of the nirK gene (Fig. S1a,b). Pearson correlation coefficients across all GC% categories varied between 0.76 and 0.93, although correlations were stronger within higher GC% categories (57%-63%; Rpearson = 0.80-0.93) than within lower GC% categories (47%-53%; Rpearson = 0.76-0.79) (Fig. S2).

sec.title: Precision of gene identification
sec.p: Target genes in the mock-communities were analyzed using both in-house and KEGG orthology Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) with precision and recall values calculated for each set of models. To determine these values, we identified which reads constituted a “true positive” or a “true negative” by mapping them to their corresponding proteomes. Protein sequences encoded by each genome were annotated using KOFAM (a customized HMM database of KEGG Orthologs). In turn, reads mapped to a given protein were assigned the function according to the above-mentioned KOFAM annotation. Matching assignments of reads from the HMMs (both in-house and from KEGG’s orthology database) were counted as true positives. Precision for the in-house HMMs ranged from 74.1% (nifH) to 100.0% (mcrA) (Fig. S4). The average precision of the models was 93.4%, with a median of 99.8% (excluding amoA and pmoA). The recall ranged from 42.8% (nxrB) to 100.0% (mcrA). The average recall was 81.9%, with a median recall of 82.8%. Because KEGG only provides a model that combined the homologous genes pmoA and amoA, it was not possible to accurately calculate the precision and recall of the in-house models for these genes. An estimate of the precision could still be determined for the two genes though, where a “true positive” meant that the hit identified by the in-house models mapped to the HMM for (a/p)moA genes provided by KEGG (K10944). In this case, the precision of amoA gene was estimated to be 96.9%, and similarly, pmoA gene was estimated to be 100.0%. It is important to note that these estimates do not exclude the possibility that the in-house models predicted that a read belonged to an amoA gene, when it actually belonged to a pmoA gene, or vice versa.

Results using KEGG Orthologs’ HMMs instead of in-house HMMs showed similar results. Note, however, that the results for amoA and pmoA genes were combined due to the model for the associated KO being the same, as mentioned above. Because KEGG only offered a model combining amoA and pmoA genes, the custom HMM produced a number of gene matches for pmoA and amoA for which also archaeal-amoA (TamoA) were possible to distinguish. Precision ranged from 76.5% (a/pmoA) to 100.0% (mcrA), while recall varied from 34.3% (nifH) to 100.0% (mcrA and nxrB). The average and median precisions were 94.5% and 97.7%, while the average and median recalls were 93.39% and 99.03%, respectively. The precision of KOs was lower for napA genes than for other genes when compared with custom DNA HMMs. This could be accounted for by the presence of formate dehydrogenase, a known homolog of napA. Formate dehydrogenase (K00123) was indeed identified among the genomes used for the mock community, so it is possible that the custom HMM was misclassifying reads originating from this known ortholog to napA (Cerqueira et al., 2015).

Overall the in-house HMM searches performed well when compared to reads mapped to the genomes and assigned KEGG Orthologs based on the full matched protein sequences, which indicates that the HMMs are able to accurately classify the reads in the mock-community. The in-house HMM was a feasible tool for detecting distantly related genes or novel clades of the gene, and can therefore be a more sensitive tool for detecting assigned KEGG Orthologs. As the results obtained with the custom HMM models generally yielded higher precision than those based on KEGG Orthologs, they were used for the final analyses. Noteworthy is that reads identified as false positives may in fact not be incorrect assignments, but could simply represent novel diversity of the genes of interest, not captured by the sequence database for the KEGG Orthologs.

sec.title: Comparison between targeted and traditional metagenomes, and PCR amplicon sequences from complex environmental samples
sec.p: We investigated the efficiency of the targeted metagenomics approach in natural complex ecosystems by directly comparing this approach with traditional untargeted metagenomes generated with a nearly 200 times higher sequencing depth (~220,000 reads and ~43 million reads per sample, respectively) in soils from a wetland in Bellefontaine, France, and from an agricultural field in Hungary (Table S2). These soils represent distinct ecosystems with average physicochemical conditions, such as water and oxygen conditions, and N availability that favor different distributions of functional genes (Jones et al. 2014). Despite the large difference in sequencing depth, targeted metagenomics generated a much larger set of target functional genes (Fig. 2), and up to 60 times as many identified gene sequences (Fig. 3), compared to traditional metagenomics. The relative abundances of functional genes in captured metagenomes correlated significantly with that in traditional metagenomes from both the agricultural field (RPearson = 0.96, d.f.=14, P < 0.00001) and the wetland (RPearson = 0.70, d.f,=14, P < 0.01). Relative target gene abundances were also not different between the two approaches (P > 0.90) (Fig. 3). However, reduced relative abundance was detected with targeted metagenomics in the agricultural site for nxrB, nrfA, narG and nosZ genes and the wetland site for nxrB, although, the targeted approach generated a much higher number of reads for these genes in both sites (P > 0.0001) (Fig. 3.). The lower relative abundance genes at the agricultural site can be due to some of the other genes being detected more efficiently with the targeted approach. The different relative abundances of functional genes in the two ecosystems reflected the expected differences in their environmental conditions: (i) N2 fixation genes were higher in the wetland, which are not fertilized; (ii) Genes involved in ammonia oxidation and in nitric and nitrous oxide reduction were higher in the agricultural soil, which are likely to be more oxic and are also subject to N fertilization resulting in higher N2O production rates ; (iii) Genes involved in methanogenesis were more abundant in the wetland, where anoxic conditions and methane production typically occur.

In order to compare the diversity of specific functional genes detected by targeted metagenomics, traditional metagenomics, and PCR amplicon sequencing, we used the archaeal amoA gene as a test case, for which there is a comprehensive reference database for classification available (Alves et al., 2018). Additionally, we compared the detection of nosZ genes between the targeted and untargeted metagenomics approaches in the agricultural soil, also based on an existing reference database (Graf et al., 2022). Comparisons were performed on different levels between: (i) targeted and traditional metagenomes, and PCR amplicons of the archaeal amoA gene in the agricultural soil (Fig. 4); (ii) targeted metagenomic reads of archaeal amoA genes in an arctic peatland soil and an archaeal amoA gene amplicon dataset (Fig. S3), generated from the same soil in a previous study (Siljanen et al., 2019); and (iii) nosZ gene sequences identified by targeted or traditional metagenomics in the agricultural soil (Fig. S4).

Comparison between agricultural and wetland soils showed that targeted metagenomics detected substantially higher diversity of archaeal amoA genes than PCR amplicon sequencing, while, as expected, traditional metagenomics detected a lower diversity than either of those two methods (Fig. 4A). Specifically, targeted metagenomics detected 71-83 distinct taxonomic amoA gene bins, whereas PCR amplicon sequencing and traditional metagenomics detected 65-68 and only two bins, respectively. Rarefaction analysis also indicated that targeted metagenomics retrieved a higher alpha diversity of archaeal amoA genes than PCR amplicon sequencing (Fig. 4B,C). Likewise, comparisons based on the peatland soils showed that targeted metagenomics detected a greater diversity of archaeal amoA genes than PCR amplicon sequencing, by detecting gene variants affiliated with nine different Nitrososphaera-related clades, in comparison with only two when amplicon sequencing was used (Fig. S3).

Targeted metagenomes yielded a higher number of taxonomic bins for nosZ genes from the agricultural soil (~6,800 bins) than traditional metagenomes (~1,300 bins) at a 90% identity cutoff, showing that the first approach detected a greater gene diversity based on much lower sequencing depth (Fig. S4). Gene sequence reads from both methods mapped to similar lineages in a comprehensive reference phylogeny of nosZ genes (Graf et al., 2022). However, a greater proportion of reads from the targeted metagenomics approach were assigned to deeper nodes of the phylogeny, particularly within the less studied clade II, suggesting that this method also captured novel nosZ variants not represented in the reference phylogeny.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We developed and evaluated a new targeted metagenomics approach using probe capture to investigate the diversity and distributions of microbial functional groups involved in the cycling of inorganic N and CH4. This included the development of an extensive set of probes targeting 15 well-established marker genes encoding key metabolic enzymes and a bioinformatic pipeline to process and annotate the sequence data. In validation experiments with mock communities comprising 18 distinct organisms, we showed that this method successfully reproduced the expected relative abundances of all target functional genes, with one exception (i.e. nirK). We observed some variation in probe specificity among mock communities with different genomic GC content, with high GC communities having generally higher target gene detection efficiency. Such variation was likely due to stronger probe hybridization to sequences with higher GC content, given the higher binding energy between guanine and cytosine than between adenine and thymine. Targeted metagenomics also accurately reproduced the relative abundances of target genes obtained with traditional untargeted metagenomics in two distinct natural microbial communities from soils, showing that the probe capture step does not introduce significant quantitative bias. Using archaeal amoA genes as a case-study, targeted metagenomics with a sequencing depth of 120-180 Mb per sample generated at least 10 times more target gene sequences than traditional metagenomics (maximum number of amoA genes among whole metagenomes was two unique taxonomic bins) and 5 times less target genes than PCR amplicon sequencing with 12-20 Gb and 2.5 Mb datasets per sample, respectively. Moreover, targeted metagenomics also detected much higher gene sequence diversity than the two other methods. For example, the new targeted approach detected 35 times higher alpha-diversity of archaeal amoA genes than traditional metagenomics in the agricultural soil, and 5 times higher diversity of nosZ genes, especially that of genes affiliated with the less characterized Clade II. In turn, the new targeted method detected 18%, and 4.5 times higher diversity of archaeal amoA genes than PCR amplicon sequencing in agricultural, and arctic peatland soils, respectively.

It should be noted that the efficiency of this approach largely depends on the coverage and quality of the database used to generate the probes. However, the database is not constrained to full-length gene sequences from a limited diversity of full genomes and long metagenomic scaffolds available, and the probe/target diversity can be greatly extended through inclusion of gene fragments generated by PCR or from short metagenomic contigs. Despite its high target precision, this method may nevertheless capture non-target sequences, especially those of enzymes that are genetically closely related but have different functions, as we observed for napA genes and those encoding formate dehydrogenases. Such cases emphasize the importance of thorough data annotation and filtering procedures.

Despite the technological advances and declines in cost of high-throughput sequencing, traditional metagenomics remains impractical and prohibitively expensive to capture the diversity of specific, low abundant functional groups in complex environments. For example, the cost of generating these datasets was 100$/sample for targeted metagenomics, >1000$/sample for traditional metagenomics, and 80$/sample per gene for PCR amplicon sequencing. In turn, PCR-based assays are limited by the biases associated with any set of primers targeting a large diversity of sequences and assay efficiencies, which also preclude detection of highly divergent new sequence diversity. The probe capture approach circumvents these limitations by using multiple short probes targeting different regions of each gene, which largely increases the likelihood of capturing sequence variants that elude PCR amplification. Thus, this approach has not only the potential to capture rare and novel gene diversity in complex environments, but also to identify cryptic microorganisms in low-biomass samples or involved in suggested metabolisms, such as in the phyllosphere (Putkinen et al., 2021) and coral holobiont (Glance et al., 2021). Moreover, targeted metagenomics also overcomes issues associated with running and comparing multiple independent PCR assays when investigating several distinct targets. In that sense, our approach effectively represents a PCR-independent, multiplex approach to characterize simultaneously and in-depth the distributions of a broad range of functional genes.

The targeted metagenomics approach developed here provides an efficient and cost-effective new strategy for studying microbial functional guilds that typically represent small fractions of natural microbiomes, and whose diversity is generally underestimated and highly underrepresented in metagenomic datasets. This approach also circumvents the limitations and biases associated with PCR-based methods and has higher potential to capture rare or novel functional gene diversity.

sec.title: Target database (TDB) collection
sec.p: A Hidden Markov Model (HMM) model was built based on reference sequence alignments from curated databases already available (Alves et al., 2018; Knief et al., 2015; Jones et al., 2014; Graf et al., 2016; fungene; WGS), or generated here from gene sequence data publicly available from their protein-coding nucleotide sequences, to cover all known diversity in each protein family. Gene sequences from environmental surveys and cultured organisms were collected from Genbank based on annotation and gene structure (hmmer profile search). Structure-based searches were performed over the whole Genbank nt-database with tblastx and nhmmer using the profile HMMs (Wheeler & Eddy, 2013) on a local supercomputer cluster (Centre of scientific computing CSC, Espoo, Finland) (July 2017). Specificity of hmm searches were confirmed by comparing the results to the latest curated sequence databases of selected genes (Alves et al., 2018; Graf et al., 2022, primary data was obtained directly from the respective authors). The final output of these searches were collected and called target gene databases (TDBs). Since some of the genes are homologous, such as amoA and pmoA genes, and nxrB and nitrate reductase genes, the respective TDBs were curated with tblastx/diamond searches against refseq database (Altschul et al., 1990) to remove some of the duplicates or move them under correct gene annotation based on curation. This sequence selection process generated ~500,000 unique sequences across all genes.

sec.title: Generation of probes for target genes
sec.p: Targeted metagenomics strategy here was developed based on the NimbleGen SeqCap EZ protocol (Roche NimbleGen, Inc.). All the nucleotide sequences from the step above (TDBs) were then processed through the SeqCap pipeline (Kushwaha, et al., 2015) with default parameters for designing up to six unique 50 mer probes for each sequence cluster (with 80% identity as the sequence clustering threshold). This produced probes on clusters produced from ~500,000 unique sequences. The target databases (TDBs) for each gene were clustered at an identity cut-off of 80% using the SeqCap pipeline (Kushwaha, et al., 2015), and up to six 50-mer probes were designed for each cluster. Information of these probes were then used to produce the NimbleGen SeqCap probe set for targeted metagenomics.

sec.title: Extraction of DNA from cultures and environmental samples
sec.p: DNA from mock communities encoding the genes of interest was generated by mixing DNA from different organisms in variable proportions, in order to simulate variation in overall GC% content. Mock communities included: Methylosinus trichosporium Ob3b, Methylocella tundrae, Methylomicrobium buryatense, Nitrosospira multiformis, Nitrososphaera viennensis, Nitrospira defluvii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Escherichia coli, Shigella sonnei, Cupriavidus metallidurans, Cupriavidus necator, Dyadobacter fermentans, Pseudomonas stutzeri, Rhodobacter sphaeroides, Salinibacter ruber, Sulfurimonas denitrificans, Methanoregula boonei, Methanolacinia petrolearia. Strain information, including genome size, number of target genes per organism, and relative abundance in mock communities are shown in Supplementary Table S1. The mock community samples used for validation of the targeted metagenomic approach, were pooled, resulting in different GC content categories due ending up to different median GC% median genome content of the genomes of each organism in the pool of targeted mock-community samples. This is, as shown as the relative abundance of the microorganism multiplying with the median genome GC content to have a weighted GC content of the pool of samples finally ending to: 47, 50, 53, 57, 60, and 63 GC%, Supplementary Table S1). Pooling of organisms was done based on the expected number of functional genes in extracted DNA, concentration of DNA, genome size, and finally it was confirmed with 16S rRNA qPCR in each DNA sample. Relative gene abundances in mock communities were calculated and compared to the sequences generated using targeted metagenomics.

Samples from different environments were collected for testing the effectiveness of the probe set to enrich functional genes in different sample contexts of various GC% produced with mock-community of cultured organism DNA. For the comparison environmental samples were collected from agricultural soil in Hungary, and from a wetland in Bellefontaine, France (Table S2). Extraction of DNA from environmental samples was performed as previously described by Siljanen et al., (2019), with phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol extraction in CTAB buffer, followed by ethanol precipitation. DNA of cultured organisms was extracted from 1% SDS treated cells in CTAB buffer, followed by phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol extraction and ethanol precipitation, as above. The quality of DNA extracts was assessed using a NanoDrop ND-1000 (Thermo), and DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit HS dsDNA kit (Thermo).

sec.title: Library preparation, pooling, target enrichment of libraries and sequencing with Illumina Miseq
sec.p: For each sample library, unique sequencing indexes and sequencing adapters were produced in the Centre for Genomic Research (CGR), University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK. These libraries were then pooled together uniformly, quality controlled with Agilent Bioanalyzer and hybridized to the NimbleGen SeqCap capturing probe set according to the manufacturer’s instructions at 47°C for 72 hours in CGR as previously described (Manoharan et al., 2015). Sequencing was done with the Illumina MiSeq PE250 chemistry. Sequencing outcome was 30,000-200,000 PE250 per environmental samples and about 2,000,000 PE250 for cultured samples.

sec.title: Shotgun sequencing with Illumina HiSeq and amoA gene amplicon sequencing
sec.p: Comparison of different sequencing strategies were done by comparing targeted metagenomics, shotgun metagenomics and amplicon sequencing of archaeal amoA genes. Shotgun metagenomic sequencing was performed on environmental DNA from agricultural soil and wetland soil. Library preparation and sequencing in one Illumina HiSeq PE150 lane were performed at the Vienna Sequencing facility, Austria and Microsynth AG, Switzerland. Archaeal amoA gene amplicons were generated with PCR conditions described earlier by Siljanen et al., (2019), and sequencing was performed with Illumina MiSeq PE250, in Munich, Germany.

sec.title: Mock-community genome protein prediction
sec.p: Validation of HMM model predictions was performed on the mock communities using independent models. Predicted proteins for the genomes used in the mock community were retrieved from NCBI. For one genome (Nitrospira defluvii; NC_014355.1), proteins were predicted from the nucleotide sequence using Prodigal (v2.6.3) (Hyatt et al., 2010). All HMM models (i.e., the models associated with each KO) for prokaryotic organisms were downloaded from KEGG and concatenated. The concatenated set of models was run against each genome using HMMER’s hmmsearch (v3.3)(Eddy, 1998). Each protein of each genome was assigned the top hitting KO. Where available, cut-offs provided with KOFAMscan (Aramaki et al., 2020) were used to filter results.

sec.title: Read preparation and mapping
sec.p: All six possible reading frames of the nucleotide sequence reads for the mock communities were translated using transeq from the EMBOSS package (v6.6.0.0). These were mapped to the genomes using DIAMOND blastp (v2.0.6.144). A minimum percentage identity of 60% was used for the mappings. No minimum coverage was used to account for reads that did not fully overlap with the proteins from the genomes. For each direction, up to four matches were retained, to account for cases where neighboring proteins were spanned by a single read. Multiple matches in the same direction could overlap by up to 15 amino acids to account for possible protein fusions or sequencing errors. Each of the, up to four, matches were used to assign KOs, based on the predicted KOs of the proteins (see above; Genome protein prediction) to which they mapped. If, in a given direction, a read was assigned the same KO multiple times, this was collapsed into a single hit, retaining the hit with the best e-value.

sec.title: Evaluating the methods for protein prediction of KO and in house-HMM searches
sec.p: Protein predictions for reads were made using HMMs downloaded from KEGG in a similar manner to that described above. For a given read, using all six of the translated frames, up to four protein assignments could be made. Frames were classified according to the best models. If a model for a KO associated with a given function of interest was assigned, then the result was filtered based on a bit score or filtration filtering. Reads assigned KOs for the function of interest were counted as positively identified hits.

In-house HMMs were built using manually curated sequences for the proteins of interest. Protein predictions for each read were performed using nhmmer from the HMMER suite (v.3.3). An inclusion threshold of 0.0001 was used when assigning protein predictions for the reads.

Counts for the true positives, false positives, and false negatives were made for all models using all methods, and precision and recall calculated. Precision was calculated as the ratio of true positives (TP) to total positive detections (i.e., all true and false positives; FP).
Recall was the ratio of true positives, to all theoretically obtainable true positives (i.e., all true positives and false negatives; FN).

Read mapping (described above) was used to determine the total possible true positives of all reads for all proteins, which was in turn used to calculate false negatives, by subtracting the total true positives from the total possible positives.

sec.title: Comparison of diversity in environmental samples produced with different sequencing strategies
sec.p: Quality trimming of sequencing reads were done with seqtk -program and in dada2 pipeline by truncating amplicon reads to 200bp and discarding all reads with expected error greater than 2. Archaeal amoA reads from amplicon and targeted and non-targeted metagenomics, were classified with pipeline utilizing commands of dada2, USEARCH8, UCHIME, UCLUST and BLASTN (Altschul et al. 1990; Edgar, 2010; Edgar et al., 2011; Caporaso et al., 2010; Callahan et al., 2016) to assign amplicon/metagenome sequence variants (A/MSVs) as earlier described (Siljanen et al., 2019) and earlier described reference database of archaeal amoA genes were used (Alves et al., 2018). (script available at: https://github.com/alex-bagnoud/arctic-nitrifiers). Relative abundance of each functional gene was quantified either using BLASTN against TDB or by using the target gene hmmer profiles to search sequences of each functional gene with maximum E-value cut-off (E < 0.001). The gene functions of each sequence were confirmed against the refseq database with tblastx in diamond sequence search accelerator (Buchfink et al., 2015). Annotation and identity information was further processed with awk in unix and in Rversion 3.5.3 to produce lists of community structures of each gene. The sequencing depths for the amoA gene amplicon library was ~10,000 PE250 reads per sample for shotgun metagenomics 40-70 M PE150 reads per sample, and for targeted metagenomics 1.4-5.8k of PE250 reads per sample.

sec.title: Phylogenetic placement of nosZ reads from shotgun and probe capture libraries
sec.p: A reference phylogeny and alignment for nosZ was generated from full length nosZ amino acid sequences obtained from genomes downloaded from the NCBI genome database (accessed October 2019). A profile HMM for nosZ was generated from a previously published nosZ dataset (Graf et al, 2022), and then used to search translated open reading frames in downloaded genomes (e-value = 0.0001). Hits were then dereplicated at 99% amino acid similarity and aligned by amino acid using hmmalign within the HMMer suite (v.3.1.2). Sequences that were homologous to nosZ were identified using FastTree (v. 2.1.11, Price et al., 2010) to generate an initial phylogeny with the resulting hits, which along with the alignment was imported into the ARB database software (Ludwig et al., 2004). The dataset was then manually curated to remove non-target homologues as well as sequences from poor quality genomes based on checkM screening (v1.0.18, Parks et al., 2015), as well as correct alignment errors. The final amino acid alignment was then used for phylogenetic analysis using IQ-TREE (v1.6.12). The Le-Gascuel (LG) substitution model with 10 rate categories was selected after automatic model selection and branch support was determined using the ultrafast bootstrap approximation, as implemented in IQ-TREE.

Phylogenetic placement of nosZ reads obtained using either shotgun metagenome sequencing or probe capture methods was performed by translating reads and aligning to the reference nosZ alignment using hmmalign. Placement of reads in the reference phylogeny was then performed using the next generation evolutionary placement algorithm (EPA-NG v0.3.8; Barbera et al., 2018), with the same model parameters as used for constructing the reference phylogeny. Placement positions with the highest likelihood weight ratio were plotted on the reference phylogeny in R using the ‘ggtree’ package (v3.4.2, Yu et al., 2016). The metagenomic, targeted metagenomic and amoA amplicon sequencing data were archived in NCBI SRA under the Bioproject numbers PRJNA898102 and PRJNA488558.
